results.content:
Very good instructor, he clearly knows his way around.
The course  content however is a little bit lacking. More tools could be used to really demonstrate how everything impacts performance such browser dev tools (the tabs timeline, network, performance, memory), jsperf, etc. ES6 and beyond is around now along with web components. jQuery is very cool and powerful but we also could see some Lodash and more functional programming.
If updating and extending the content is not a possibility I would at least note that this course is related to basic best practices to achieve better perceived performance and mention what not to expect.
results.content_html:

More tools could be used to really demonstrate how everything impacts performance such browser dev tools (the tabs timeline, network, performance, memory), jsperf, etc. ES6 and beyond is around now along with web components. jQuery is very cool and powerful but we also could see some Lodash and more functional programming.
If updating and extending the content is not a possibility I would at least note that this course is related to basic best practices to achieve better perceived performance and mention what not to expect.

results.content: I'm at a JavaScript lower intermediate level. This course was good for me to study, if I only consider the concepts & temporarily (& partially) overlook (Ben Fhala) the instructor's code. I really need to re-study this when I achieve an advanced level. In the future, this will be a very important course to improve my coding. I gave it 5 stars based on my anticipation, that I will be able to keep up with the instructor's fast pace of replacing bad code with good code. This is partially an advanced course, because the instructor assumes you easily understand his code & (to a degree) memorized his variable names. I wish the instructor used smaller (per concept) scripts instead of constantly scrolling through his one giant multi-purpose script. Then, (maybe) this course could be a consistent intermediate level. Still, I learned many important concepts. Note: I previously studied this instructor's JavaScript OOP course.

results.content: Many good tips and practical examples, the walk-trough is on an easy-to-follow pace.
results.content_html: Many good tips and practical examples, the walk-trough is on an easy-to-follow pace.

results.content:
The information is good, liked how we focused on one simple app.
But the class could flow a lot better.
The good was that we got to see some of the debug process.
A pity that he did not slow down and explain what he was doing during these debug sessions.
There is no value in seeing another person looking through code for a problem without explaining what they are looking for and why.

results.content:
There are a lot of great concepts in this course. I feel like this course would be very beneficial to anyone not familiar with performance tuning or best practices in JavaScript.

One way I think the course could have been dramatically improved is by starting off with a blank slate and working through building a mini-application that teaches these practices.
results.content_html:
There are a lot of great concepts in this course. I feel like this course would be very beneficial to anyone not familiar with performance tuning or best practices in JavaScript.

One way I think the course could have been dramatically improved is by starting off with a blank slate and working through building a mini-application that teaches these practices.

results.content: I am learning things about how to make my JavaScript application  have better performance, but the only things that erks me a little is that Ben doesn't know how to pronounce certain terms or words correctly.  In most cases it's not a big deal, but it's still a little annoying.  This is the third course I've taken by Ben Fhala, and while I can tell he knows what he's talking about, but not knowing how to pronounce "eval" is just bad.  I would have thought he would have heard it spoken in the community by someone.

I would have thought he would have heard it spoken in the community by someone.
